characters: FISHER AND LIZ STILL IN LINE
MICHAEL AND BOYD AT THE BAR
THE HORRIFIED EXPRESSIONS OF BOYD, MOORE AND FISHER

dialogues.speaker: THE DEAD OF NIGHT
dialogues.text: Pitch black. Dead quiet. Dim faint light appears in the  distance, approaching, growing larger. As the light nears we recognize car headlights. Closer and closer until the is bearing down upon us with great force...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two men in the front seat, FISHER and MOORE. Fisher drive All seems quite normal until we take a closer look, sweat matts hair, dirt stains on white tuxedo shirts hands are  blistered and bloody. They seem almost entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ought to be about the end of  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. PUSH IN ON Fisher...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Oakland Raiders have taken a 7 -  6 lead in a, tough, football game  and this crowd is standing..."

dialogues.speaker: DECEMBER 23RD, 1972
dialogues.text: Playoff game between the Oakland Raiders and the Pittsbur Steelers. Scoreboard reads: 22 seconds, 4th down, 10 yard to go, 4th quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Hang on to your hats, here come the  Steelers out of the Huddle..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: transfixed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It comes down to one big play, 4th  down, ten yards to go. Terry Bradshaw  at the controls..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradshaw throws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And Bradshaw, back and  looking...Again, Bradshaw running  out of the pocket... Looking for  someone to throw to..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradshaw throws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Bradshaw fires it down the field  and there's a collision!..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball bounces off the helmet of a Raider player and is caught low by the Steelers' FRANCO HARRIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...and it's caught out of the air!  The ball is pulled in by Franco  Harris!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franco Harris running for the end  zone, all but home..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oncoming headlights illuminate Fisher's face... END TITLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOWLY TRACKING down a long line of couples. Some with ki some old, some young, all waiting to pay their $55 and pi up their marriage license. We HOLD on a young couple, late 20's, KEITH FISHER and hi fiancee, LIZ GARRETY. Fisher has a blondish quality to hi unassuming, pleasant, attentive, a bit more reactive than could be. Liz is quite attractive, but somewhat tense, an not at all happy about having to stand in this very slow  moving line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Government cutbacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't we do it through the mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patient) We missed the deadline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we do it on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of them a middle-aged MEXICAN COUPLE make-out  intensely while their chubby little THREE YEAR OLD stares Liz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is this Kid staring at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz pulls a note-pad out of her daypack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from her  notes) Did you send in all of the deposit  checks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) What do you mean, you think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent a lot of checks, I'm not sure  what all of them are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding cake check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sent it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Photographer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sent it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caterer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hotel for my parents, the tent, the  band, the Judge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I think I forgot the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat alarmed) You forgot the tent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you forget the tent check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to Liz. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't play around with these  tent people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not playing around. I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else have you forgot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I know what else I forgot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working my ass off here. I've  taken care of absolutely everything  Keith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you wanted to. You wanted  this to be your wedding not your  parent's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you put this on me. Don't do  it, don't do it, don't do it, don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG TEENAGE COUPLE behind them stares at Liz, a bit  confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to calm her) Stop it. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to control  herself) You know how important this is to my  mother. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm sorry I forgot the  tent. I don't think I forgot anything  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not bitchy) I bet you didn't forget the bachelor  party checks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we going to do this again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying I bet those checks  all found the mailboxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It amazes me how organized you and  your little fun bunch can be when it  comes time to mobilize to Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patient) They organized this, not me. I have  nothing to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's bad timing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you figure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right before the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bachelor party. You sort of  have to do it before the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose Boyd is the creative force  behind all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my friend. He's not a moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Boyd is a big sack of hot gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON a "Fred Sands" realty sign being pounded into th ground. Pictured on the sign, as "offered by," is realtor DAVID BOYD, 30-ish, short hair, smiling with bizarre  sincerity. WIDER to reveal, David Boyd in the flesh, suit jacket off pounding away, sinking the sign into the front yard of a  cute little house. His CELL PHONE RINGS. Boyd, gets the p from his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) David Boyd. Tina. Great. Okay. Here's  the deal, we're talking five guys.  Hard Rock. Nice guys Tina. My friends.  Yeah. I'm calling you directly so  you don't have to go through the  agency... (suddenly, over his  shoulder) HEY! DO NOT ENTER THE HOUSE! (back into phone) That's correct. Cash straight to  you. Yes. Twelve hundred? I don't  think so. It's just stripping. Just  a show. Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you please wait off the  property?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON A YOUNG COUPLE, obviously here to see the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just trying to sneak a peak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stay off the property until I'm  off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause that's the way they do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bewildered and somewhat intimidated, they back off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back into phone) So it's five guys, Hard Rock Casino.  Nine hundred bucks and you do the  thing with the rubber hoses. Are you  in? Tina, are you in? Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boyd hangs up, puts on his jacket and turns with the same bizarre insincere smile in his photo. Hand extended...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Boyd, nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you feel the need to explore  this side of your personality?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about the kind of people  you hang out with... about growing  up, assuming responsibility of  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you to marry me. I'm ready  for marriage. That's responsibility.  That's growth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just think that at some point you're  going to have to re-evaluate some of  your friendships...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Moore for instants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like Moore? Since when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that I don't like him. But  the wedding has really got me thinking  and... I just keep myself opening  up. Growning. And I want you keeping  up with me here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does Moore have to do with your  growing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't see him in the big  picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've known him since Cub Scouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's weird.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON
dialogues.text: Late twenties, a chef in a very upscale, very busy KITCHE His name, "Moore," is embroidered on his white chef's jac Food orders fly all around as Moore works with a mesmeriz focus, a poetic sense of purpose, fifteen things going on once; he chops, sautes, braises, etc..., in a perfect mut silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just doesn't talk a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What's his problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a great chef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's weird. And I expect more from  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect more what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to be hungover for three  days. Like those guys on "Oprah"  that get drunk and have disgusting  sex with prostitutes and then say  their vows with the stench of cheap  hotel whore sex all over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's vile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's absurd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen it on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to marry you with the  smell of prostitutes on my body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to cry) I am not common Keith. I am not  common. I am a creature like no other  and I will not be commoned! Is that  to much to ask? (screaming) Is that to much to ask!?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not be common!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, at the head of the line, Liz steps up to the cle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marriage license please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fisher and Liz emerge, start for the parking lot. Liz sto to look at Fisher, her eyes well with tears, vulnerable a apologetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vulnerable) Kiss me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FISHER takes her into his arms, pulls her to him, kisses hard, for all it's worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desk after desk after desk of identical men, seemingly  repeating the same task. We find Fisher at one of the des number crunching. At the desk across from Fisher sits... MICHAEL BRENN, short, compact, with a severe personality  disorder, masquerading as semi-appropriate behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just insecurity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. She's really been  stressing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just insecurity. Nut crunching gut  splinters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means she's insecure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael's phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up) Mike Brenn. Yes. Yes. 14.3 at 7.5  for 6. At 29.83 at 9. (hangs up) I'm amazed the windows don't blow  out of their fucking sockets with  all the repressed, ass-puckering  rage in these soul-less lizards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I just want her to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same alarm clock every morning, same  two pops on the same snooze button... (PHONE RINGS; picks  up) Michael Brenn. Yes... Yes... (looking through stacks  of stats) Hold your horses. Okay. Got it. 6.321  at 17.28 for 6.6 at 9.256 out at  3432.343. (hangs up) Same shower, towel, toothbrush, razor,  hair gel. It's a fucking epidemic  Fisher and you better start addressing  it. You're getting married and I'm  not going to candy-coat it. It just  gets worse. It's an eighteen wheel  cement mixer that will crush every  bone in your body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fisher looks pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not breathing right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not breathing right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lately I'll just start getting  lightheaded, dizzy, and I realize I  haven't breathed in like two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ADAM BRENN, Michael's older brother, mid-30's, a bit soft the belly, approaches, more or less in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Michael) We're leaving from my house in three  hours. If you want to come, get your  numbers in order by then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts him off) No first of all. I'm not in a game  mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're interrupting a personal  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fisher) Sorry Fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be ready Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you'll be. (to Michael) Three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fisher's phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pick's up) Keith Fisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz sits at the kitchen table, in a mild panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) We've got problems here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT Liz and Fisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seating problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keith do not trivialize this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supposed to have gold-trimmed  padded seats, now they're telling me  that there was a mistake and we can't  have padded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of seats can we have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not padded ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go down where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go down to the seat place and  straighten this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey I don't have the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're leaving in three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to cry) I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call them from the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than I ever imagined being able  to love anyone ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of those chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're leaving from Adam's. Come send  me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOYD, MOORE, FISHER in the middle, MICHAEL and his older  brother, ADAM, all in suits pose in front of Adam's brand new, state of the art, Chevy Minivan while Adam's very  aggressive wife, LOIS, mired in domestic resentment, focu her camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notice how clean and well-behaved  they all appear, respectable members  of modern society. Timmy, Adam Jr.,  take a good look at this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's and Lois' kids, Timmy, 8, and Adam Jr., 10, watch  with Liz. (Adam Jr., in leg braces and crutches, suffers  from muscular dystrophy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We will compare these before photos  with whatever form of degeneration  presented to us in 24 hours, no matter  how low, how vile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...embarrassing, shameful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...regression of Modern Man to his  most primitive, ape-like state...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stone age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The post-Vegas Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mutant species.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay boys, smile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lois clicks off photos of the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. As you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys break. Fisher goes to Liz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please call the chair people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call and let me know that your  okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice bachelor party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam kisses Lois and the kids goodbye. Adam Jr. nearly lo his balance in the excitement, Adam catches him. Boyd starts to get in the drivers seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not on your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boyd slides over shotgun, cranks the MUSIC. Fisher's the  last one in. He slides the big Minivan door shut and they off. Adam looks in the rearview mirror, Lois, Liz, Timmy wave  goodbye. Adam Jr. waves one of his crutches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minivan cruises east: from Santa Monica; through down Los Angeles; and the City of Industry. At the turn off, a freeway sign reads; "Las Vegas 385 miles."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fucking moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fucking opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really a stupid opinion. You  have developed an annoying habit of  talking for what seems to be no other  reason than to hear yourself speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my opinion threatens yours,  it's poorly developed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, because your opinions are idiotic  and have nothing to do with what any  given conversation is about, which  makes 85% of your eagerly injected  thought process highly offensive to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boyd brought up divorce statistics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell I did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell you didn't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell I did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said one in two marriages end in  divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that Boyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an asshole Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and why am I an asshole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Multiple reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHUT UP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAD SILENCE. As they ride through the lifeless desert, F dials his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Is this Pico Party rents? Can I speak  to whomever is in charge of chairs?  Chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boyd checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hours and fifteen minutes. I  can make Vegas in 3 and change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not getting a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on cell phone) Tony? This is Keith Fisher. You're  doing my wedding and I'm calling  about the chair situation. Yeah,  I'll hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's up for making some real money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hear me out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. (into phone) Yes, the Fisher wedding chairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prison Communication Systems. (no response) An acquaintance friend of mine is  professionally involved with a  communications outfit in Denver that  I just happen to know for a fact is  about to be rewarded a very large,  exclusive contract to rewire every  state prison in Colorado. Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody gives a fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No, I'm holding for Tony. In chairs.  Keith Fisher. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would translate to government  guaranteed contract in excess of 35  million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) We need padded chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a stock kick of approximately  125% on shares which are currently  sitting around $4.38, or, in plain  English...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHUT UP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you people? I'm a  helper here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your investment ideas never work  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the whole point. They rarely  work out. But on occasion they do.  And when they do, they do big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your ideas never work out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really? Starbucks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No... we want padded chairs... okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One idea that if you had fucking  listened to, you would each be worth  approximately 15 million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't keep bringing up Starbucks.  That was your only real hit in like  75 tries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I set up Fisher with the broker that  found his house. Took care of that  one, didn't I? (beat) Prison Communications.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so Boyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Don't come crying to Boyd. No  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
